ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BUDGET ALLOCATION FOR MINISTRY OF DEFENCE



    1. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Finance what is the justification for the allocation to the Ministry of Defence of the largest share of the Budget for FY 1994/95, amounting to 27% of the total budget and an increase of 3% over the allocation for 1993.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, Question No. 1. With your permission, I would like to point out that the year 1993 in the Question refers to financial year 1992/93. I apologise for the typographical error.

     The Minister of State for Finance (Cdre Teo Chee Hean) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member's question focuses on the share of the Government's total budget allocated to the Ministry of Defence. For FY 1994, this amounts to 27% of the total budget as compared to 30% of the total budget in FY 93. This is a decline of 3 percentage points. Dr Soin may have misread the percentages. Be that as it may, the share that is allocated to defence from the total Government budget is not a particularly meaningful figure, as it depends on what other services the Government provides directly and what it provides indirectly, eg, through statutory boards like PUB, privatised companies like Singapore Telecom, or restructured hospitals like SGH.

    Unlike other activities, defence and security cannot be privatised and must be provided by the Government. Hence, its share of the Government budget might appear large.

    A more appropriate measure of the size of the defence budget is as a percentage of GDP. The Government has set aside up to 6% of the GDP for defence. As Singapore has developed and grown, this 6% for defence has correspondingly increased, without ever becoming a burden on the economy, or depriving us of resources for other public purposes.

Column: 1363

Spending on defence has never held back expenditure on education, health or housing. Whenever we have not proceeded with a project, it is because the Government has considered it to be an unwise or uneconomic use of funds, and not because funds are not available.

    The 6% limit on defence expenditure has remained unchanged for many years. But Mindef does not automatically spend the entire 6% each year. Depending on the SAF's needs, in some years, less is spent. Provided the cost of military equipment does not escalate too quickly, and economic growth remains strong, we can continue to do so. In FY 94, Mindef's budget is 5.2% of GDP. This is similar to the level of expenditure in recent years.

    Singaporeans must never believe that peace can be taken for granted or that security can be ensured by default. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the civil war in Bosnia remind us that Singaporeans cannot survive by someone else's largesse. We have to make adequate preparations ourselves to safeguard our own survival. Nobody else will do it for us.

    Steady expenditure on defence is therefore necessary for our survival. It is an insurance premium that provides a secure and stable environment that attracts investments and lets Singaporeans enjoy continued economic growth. My Ministry will continue to support Mindef's operations through the provision of sufficient, but not excessive, financial resources.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, I appreciate the Minister's reply, and I am with most of it. But could I ask him whether he thinks 27% of the total budget allocation for defence, as compared to 1.6% for community development, is a good allocation of resources?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I pointed out just now, spending on defence has never prevented us from spending enough money on these other areas.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: I agree with that. If we reduce 1% on defence, it would not

Column: 1364

make a great deal of difference to the defence budget but it would add a lot to the community development budget.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me put it this way. We are a small country and we have to spend enough on defence to make sure that we are in a stable and secure situation so that foreign investors would feel comfortable to come here and do business. When our children do national service, it is a sign that they are prepared to defend the country and to place a long-term stake in the future of the country. When we spend on defence, we show that we are prepared to do the same and this sends a very strong signal to others that we are prepared to stay here, sink our roots in, and defend what we have. This is a very important element in creating the right environment for our prosperity and growth.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: I think our leaders have done a very good job in building very cordial relationship with our neighbours, and right now we are in ---

     Mr Speaker: Dr Soin, no speeches. Can you ask your question?

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: In view of this very cordial relationship, would the Minister agree that defence spending is not as important as it would be during less cordial time?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have never built our defence on the basis of the state of relations with any particular country. We have built our defence on the basis that we have to be prepared for the future and that we have to be prepared to defend ourselves. That is the basis. If I may remind the hon. Member, the fact that the Cold War may have ended, for example, is not an indication at all that times have necessarily become better or more secure for the countries in our region.

CIVIL SERVANTS ON CO-PAYMENT ON WARD CHARGES SCHEME
(Formula for salary revision)


    2. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Finance if he will state what is the formula for salary revision for those civil

Column: 1365

servants who want to stay on the Co-payment on Ward Charges (CPW) scheme of the medical benefits package before they are asked to sign the option form.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Service Division will be tracking the costs of medical subsidies to officers on the Co-Payment on Ward Charges (CPW) Scheme and those on the Comprehensive Co-Payment Scheme (CCS). This, together with the actual magnitude of the salary adjustment for each group of officers in the next revision, will be used to determine the differential salary gain between civil servants on the CPW and the CCS.

    It is thus not possible to state a formula at this juncture. I can, however, assure all civil servants that it will be fair and equitable to those on the CPW as well as those on the CCS.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Sir, would the Minister agree that it would be difficult to make an informed decision without some indication, whether it is going to be half on the co-payment charges or one-quarter of the salary revision, so that the civil servant could have a better idea of which system to opt for?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, the future salary revision will be made on a fair and equitable basis depending on the actual magnitude of the salary adjustment at that point in time and the way the health care costs develop.

Column: 1365

PRIVATISATION OF SINGAPORE TELECOM
(Engagement of American lawyers)


    3. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Finance whether American lawyers were engaged in the privatisation of Singapore Telecom.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. In the privatisation of Singapore Telecom, Sullivan and Cromwell of New York were engaged by Temasek Holdings

Column: 1366

and Singapore Telecom to advise on international law, including US law in relation to the international tranche.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, why was there a need to advise on international law when the privatisation was carried out in Singapore?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member should be aware that the laws regarding commercial transactions in different countries may be different and therefore specialised legal advice was required for a listing of this kind which was put out in many different countries.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Is the Minister saying that there is no such expertise available in the local law firms?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, for a privatisation of this kind where it is a very large and complicated privatisation process, I think it is prudent to go to where the knowledge resides.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, would the Minister agree that this does not seem to be in congruence with the Government's decision to sever its links with the Privy Council? We said that we in Singapore want to establish a legal practice or legal standard by ourselves.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member has got the two issues quite unnecessarily confused together. Whether or not we go to the Privy Council is a separate issue, ie, whether we consider them to be an appropriate body to take up appeals in particular cases. Here, we have gone to engage experts in this area in order to advise us on what are the correct procedures in the case of a public offering of shares.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: There are two questions here: Firstly, what is the legal cost of engaging the American lawyers? Secondly, I asked the question why there was no competent law firm or expert in Singapore who could give the same sort of service.

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: Sir, the issue at hand here is going to where the best advice is available. As I said, the Singapore Telecom offer was a very large

Column: 1367

offer made in many different countries and we should go to the lawyers who could offer us the correct advice in these countries so that the share offer could proceed without legal hitches.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang; Sir, what about the legal costs involved?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: I do not have all the costs before me. But the segment that I have suggests that the fees are in the order of US$145,000 plus expenses. Seen in relation to the size of the offer, I think this is quite reasonable.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the privatisation exercise was done in Singapore, but the Minister mentioned about going to the best lawyers for advice on international law because of the huge public offer of shares. Why was there a need to do that? Would the Minister explain further?

     Cdre Teo Chee Hean: I would be glad to enlighten the Member on the intricacies of such a share offering, particularly when it involves many other countries. While Singapore Telecom is a Singapore company, the Member should know that the shares were also on offer to nationals and companies in many other countries. The 'C' tranche, for example, of 450 million shares initially on offer was a very large offer and was taken up by many investors in many different countries quite successfully because of the advice given.

COST REVIEW COMMITTEE REPORT
(Translation)


    4. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Information and the Arts when the translation of the Cost Review Committee Report will be ready, and why his Ministry has taken such a long time for the translation.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Chinese translation has just been completed. The Malay and Tamil versions are being translated and should be ready soon.

Column: 1368



    MITA has a small Translation Unit. The Report is 229 pages with many technical terms, charts and tables. The translation of the Report had to be done together with the other urgent work. The CRC Secretariat was aware of MITA's manpower constraint.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, could I take it that that was because of low priority given by MITA in the translation of the CRC Report? It has taken, I think, almost a year to finish the translation.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, the Report was made public at the end of September 1993. I do not have an abacus here, but I think it is less than half a year. The point is that from January to March this year the Translation Unit was heavily loaded with more urgent work, including the translation of the Civil Service medical benefits booklet and the translation of many important documents relating to projects in China.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, how many staff are there in the Ministry's Translation Unit?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: We have eight Chinese translators and we put three or four of the more senior translators to work on the CRC Report because of the importance of that Report.

Column: 1368

MEDISAVE WITHDRAWAL FOR COMMUNITY HOSPITALS
(Rationale for limit)


    5. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Health what is the rationale for the limit of Medisave withdrawal of $100 per day for community hospitals as compared to $300 per day for restructured hospitals when the ward charges for community hospitals are 80% of those for restructured hospitals.

     The Minister for Health (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Sir, with effect from 1st January 1994, the withdrawal limit for community hospitals was raised to $150 a day. The daily withdrawal limit is lower for community hospitals because their charges are also lower.

Column: 1369



    In deciding on the withdrawal limit for community hospitals, consideration was given to their total daily hospital charges, and not just the ward charges which form only a part of the total hospital bill.

    The average daily hospital charges in the Ang Mo Kio Community Hospital are about half those in the restructured acute hospitals. This excludes the surgical fees for which there are separate Medisave withdrawal limits which are the same for both the community and acute hospitals. We have therefore pegged the withdrawal limit for the daily hospital charges at community hospitals to half that for the acute hospitals.

    The withdrawal limit of $150 a day will be adequate to cover the full Class B2 and C bills in a community hospital.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin: Would the Minister agree that the ward charges in a community hospital are 80% of those for restructured hospitals? If the Minister agrees, what I am asking is that the withdrawal should then be 80% of the ward charges because the $300 per day just refers to ward charges. The second reason I am asking the question is this: I feel that if you do not allow enough withdrawals for ward charges, it could discourage patients from wanting to stay in community hospitals and that would prolong their stay in the tertiary hospitals.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, I thank Dr Soin for her concern. As I mentioned earlier, what we are concerned with is total medical bill, not just ward charges. If I can give the Member some numbers: the average daily hospital charge in Ang Mo Kio Community Hospital for C class ward is $34 compared to $79 in the restructured hospital, and we are allowing the limit of $150, not including surgical fees. For B2, it is $63 at Ang Mo Kio Community Hospital compared to $135 in the restructured hospital. This is again easily covered by the $150 limit.

AREA LICENSING SCHEME ON SATURDAYS
(Lifting from 10.15 am onwards)


    6. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider lifting the Area Licensing Scheme on Saturdays from 10.15 am onwards.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member's proposal will be taken into consideration when we review the whole-day Area Licensing Scheme (ALS). This review will be done after the PWD completes a comprehensive survey of the traffic situation in the Central Business District in the next one or two months.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew (Nominated Member): In the meantime, Sir, would the Minister consider giving it a trial run of, say, two months, by lifting the ALS after 10.15 am on Saturdays?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the purpose of the review is to give us a picture of the real situation after the traffic situation in the CBD has stabilised. If we were to conduct a trial run, as the Member suggested, I think it would only confuse the picture and we would not have the true picture of what actually is the result of the whole-day ALS.

     Mr Robert Chua Teck Chew: But I suggest that this be looked into because that is one way of comparing with and without the lifting of the ALS on Saturday afternoons, otherwise you only get one picture.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I said, it is more accurate to have a full picture of what is happening when the situation stabilises. Right now, everything is still in a state of flux.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Computer balloting of flats)


    7. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Acting Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will (i) enlighten the public on how its computer balloting of flats is conducted; (ii) assure the public that no

Column: 1371

computer fraud can be attempted under the system; and (iii) invite the public to witness the process of computer balloting.

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Sir, HDB flats are offered for booking in two types of estates: non-mature and mature estates.

    In the balloting for non-mature estates, where there is more land available for development, priority is accorded to new applicants over upgraders. New applicants, who have never bought a flat direct from HDB before, are given higher chances of success than upgraders. Applicants who have been unsuccessful for many times are also given greater chances of success than applicants who have tried for fewer times.

    For mature estates, priority is given in the balloting to resident over non-resident applicants. Resident applicants are defined as those who have been residing in the mature estate of their application for more than five years. In the computer balloting for mature estates, resident applicants are accorded higher chances of success than non-resident applicants. The actual number of flats apportioned to each category, of course, depends on the total number of flats available, and the number of resident and non-resident applicants.

    In using the computer balloting system, HDB has built in all the controls necessary to ensure that the system is fair to all applicants. The system itself, as well as the actual balloting carried out every quarter, is audited both by HDB's internal auditors and by independent private auditing firms, selected by way of open tender. The auditors check for system integrity, and ensure that the balloting is carried out impartially and in accordance with HDB's flat allocation policies.

    Since the balloting process is done through the computer, I am not sure what or how the Member wants the public to witness in this processing. In any case, HDB distributes information leaflets on the Booking System to all flat applicants. The public is also kept informed of the

Column: 1372

priority accorded to the different categories of applicants, through the mass media. In addition, the number of flats offered each quarter, the results of balloting, and the success rates for each new town are advertised by HDB in all the major newspapers.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister says that there are some built-in controls to ensure the integrity of the system. What are the controls that have been built in to ensure that there will be no fraud? Would the Minister make public the auditors' reports on the computer balloting system?

    As regards inviting the public to witness the balloting, I am referring to the actual running of the computer itself. When you run the selection, would someone be present to witness it?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the system controls are the standard controls put in for all computer applications: separation of different programmes, code words, code entries, ie, the standard controls for system applications.

    As for the auditors' reports, I am sure they are available. I would ask HDB to consider whether this can be made known to the public.

    As to what the public can see when we run the system, again I would ask HDB what they can actually witness when HDB runs the computer. Do they visit the computer room and hear the whirring of the computer being operated? I will check it out and see whether it is worthwhile to invite the public to witness it.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I think the HDB should make the procedure clearer, from the time the applications are submitted, how they are keyed into the computer, how the computer prioritises or rates the priority of, let us say, new applicants in mature estates, and how are they given the priority. I think at present the procedures are quite vague and abstract.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Low, no speeches.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, as I have explained, there are two categories of priorities. The first category is whether you are a first-time buyer or you are an

Column: 1373

upgrader. If you are a first-time buyer, as I have explained in this House many times, you are given a year's headstart. So you join the same group of people who have applied one year ago. So new applicants are given one year's headstart compared to upgraders.

    Secondly, within that same group of people who apply in the same quarter, the computer will ballot through random number generators who gets the first number to be selected and so on down the line. As for the process of balloting, these are the people who form the queue positions in selecting the flats. It is quite a straightforward process.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: What about the procedure of keying in?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: They just type it in.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (remained seated): Who keys into the computer?

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Low, are you asking a question?

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Clarification, Sir. What I am asking is, first of all, what are the safeguards that you have from the time a person receives the application up to the time it is keyed into the computer? How does the computer actually prioritise, let us say, by giving one year's headstart to a new applicant compared to an upgrader? How does the computer categorise that and through what system?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, if the Member is so interested in these details I will get HDB to give him a private tutorial and give him all the codes and teach him how to key in.

ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR
1ST APRIL, 1994 TO 31ST MARCH, 1995


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [8th Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head J -
1.58 pm

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua)( In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 1374



    That the sum to be allocated for Head J of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, for the past few weeks, we have heard many comments from our colleagues in this House on the problem of family violence, juvenile delinquency, divorces, aged parents and other issues. But at the bottom of them all, the problem actually arises because of changes to the family structure and family values. As the Chinese saying goes, "Cultivate oneself, raise a family, govern the country and there will be peace to all under heaven." You must be able to keep a family well before you can govern a country and have peace and harmony. So we must be very clear in our mind about the right values and the right concepts.

    The Ministry of Community Development has to take care of many issues apart from politics and economy, such as the livelihood of the poor, the aged, the sick, the deaf, marriages, family disputes, feedback, etc. All these are very wide ranging issues handled by one single Ministry and very often you can see the result of newly implemented policies only after three to five years. In this very pragmatic and utilitarian society, we still have a group of people who are prepared to sacrifice their time to work for the community and to maintain social cohesiveness. I think I should salute these volunteers and social workers. At the same time, I would like to appeal to the Ministry of Finance to consider allocating more funds to MCD so that the Ministry would have sufficient resources to meet the various needs in implementing long-term plans.

    When I look at the 1989 report of the Family and Social Community Advisory Committee, I notice that a lot of recommendations have been accepted and implemented, and the Ministry of Community Development has been very fast in doing so. The report has about 10 pages of recommendations such as creches which look after 20,000 young children; for the aged, they have the Community Clubs for the aged; all kinds of schemes like the Family Service Centres and subsidies for the poor families in

Column: 1375

terms of utilities, and, recently, we also have the Small Families Improvement Scheme.

    All these measures have been well implemented and I think we should appreciate the work done by the MCD. I am not singing praises of MCD for its own sake. I think many of the policies of the Government have not been transmitted to the various levels because many people are busy, so they tend to be rather absent-minded and even in this House, we can hear only complaints against the policies, but very few praises. There is one saying to the effect that good deeds are seldom known, whereas bad deeds spread very far. I think this is the problem that we have to face. We must be able to show care and love, respect, dedication, commitment and responsibility. I think the MCD has conducted many forums on these. But on family values, I think these are all very abstract concepts. We must know how we are going to link this with the reality of life.

    We have three targets for the propagation of family values. One is the Government. The Government has already formulated one set of formula and there are provisions which state very clearly what we should do to establish the correct family values. At the same time, the Government should allocate more resources and funds for the implementation of the programme.

Column: 1432

separate amendment consequential to the abolition of appeals to the Privy Council. The amendments to the Constitution are: (a) Clause 2 - an amendment to Article 34(2)(a); (b) Clause 3 - a repeal of Article 100; and (c) Clause 4 - a new Article 111A.

    Article 34(2)(a) of the Constitution, as currently worded, provides for appointments to the grade of Permanent Secretary to be made by the President, acting in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister, from a list of names submitted by the Public Service Commission. The grade of Permanent Secretary exists only in the Administrative Service and Administrative (Foreign Service) Schemes, where grades at Superscale C and above are designated as Permanent Secretary grades.

    Because of Article 34(2)(a), an officer in the Administrative Service or the Administrative Service (Foreign Service Branch) can only be promoted to the grade of Superscale C if he is also appointed a Permanent Secretary. This was not a constraint when the civil service was small, most functions were handled by Ministries, and few officers reached Superscale C. Today, the range of top jobs in the civil service has widened, but the number of Ministries and Permanent Secretary posts has remained the same. Many senior Administrative Officers are not performing the statutory duties of a Permanent Secretary, but are holding posts which justify Superscale C grades. For them, the term "Permanent Secretary" is a misnomer.

    The Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) of large statutory boards, like MAS, HDB or NUS, have jobs which are equivalent in size to or even larger than some Permanent Secretary posts. Many statutory board CEOs are Administrative Officers. But Article 34(2)(a) does not allow us to promote such an officer to Superscale C, unless he is at the same time appointed a Permanent Secretary, even though he does not run a Ministry.

Column: 1433

Administrative Officers of at least Superscale C grade, but only one or at most two Permanent Secretary posts. Article 34(2)(a) prevents us from promoting Deputy Secretaries in these Ministries to Grade C and above, unless they become the Permanent Secretary or are posted out to another Ministry. Deputy Secretaries can be at most Superscale D1, even if the Permanent Secretary is Staff Grade.

    These rigidities hinder the timely advancement and flexibile deployment of able Administrative Officers. Clause 2 of the Bill therefore seeks to amend Article 34(2)(a) to provide for appointments to the office of Permanent Secretary, instead of to the grade of Permanent Secretary, to be made by the President, acting in accordance with the advice of the Prime Minister, from a list of names submitted by the Public Service Commission.

    In future, the term "Permanent Secretary" will refer only to Administrative Officers heading a Ministry, ie, those holding the office of Permanent Secretary. The actual grade held by a Permanent Secretary will vary depending on the seniority of the officer and the size of the Ministry. This delinking of rank and grade will offer more flexibility in the promotion and deployment of Administrative Officers in the entire public sector and within a Ministry.

    Despite its rigidity, the old Article 34(2)(a) did serve a function, as it vested the final decision as to whom to promote to Superscale C in the Administrative Service with the Prime Minister, who would promote from a list put up by the PSC. This is right as the Prime Minister and Cabinet work closely with the Permanent Secretaries and senior civil servants, and are in a position to make first hand assessments of the abilities and performances of these senior officers. On its own, the revised Article 34(2)(a) would no longer provide for the Prime Minister to decide on promotion of officers into the topmost echelons of the Administrative Service.

    To remedy this, clause 4 of the Bill seeks to insert a new Article 111A to provide for the designation of a "Significant Grade" in

    The Significant Grade will be established by gazette notification, and can be raised from time to time. The status quo would be to set the Significant Grade at Superscale C, the present lowest Permanent Secretary grade. However, in today's environment, a more realistic benchmark grade for Permanent Secretaries is Superscale B. This is because even with the latest salary revisions, Administrative Service Superscale salaries still lag too far behind the private sector. SHELTER FOR BATTERED WIVES


    18. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Acting Minister for Community Development if his Ministry will consider running a secular shelter for battered wives as there is no shelter run by a non-religious organisation.

     Mr Abdullah Tarmugi:

    There are 4 shelters for battered wives run by 3 established organisations. These are the Good Shepherd Centre run by the Catholic Welfare Services, the Whampoa Care and Elliot Road Centres run by the Anglican Welfare Council and the Pertapis Female Centre run by Pertapis. These centres are open to any woman regardless of race or religion. No needy women has been denied access to these centres.

    Except for the Good Shepherd Centre which has plans to expand its capacity of 25, the other centres are running below capacity. The centres run by the Anglican Welfare Council have a population of 52 against a capacity of 70. The Pertapis Centre has a population of 38 against a capacity of 60.

    The Government does not see a need to duplicate the good work done by these welfare organisations.
